TUESDAY’S FORECAST: 1/2/24
Happy New Year, and Happy Tuesday!
According to the
National Weather Service in San Juan, Puerto Rico, Tuesday will be sunny, as a ridge of high pressure over the region is expected to help keep the islands relatively dry. The high temperature will be approximately 85°F, 29.4°C, with winds out of the east at about 10 to 15 mph, gusting up to 20 mph. The chance of rain on Tuesday is less than 10%.
Tuesday night will be mostly clear, with a slight chance of isolated showers overnight. The low temperature will be approximately 74°F, 23.3°C, with winds out of the east-southeast at about 5 to 13 mph. The possibility of rain on Tuesday night is about 10%.
Below: Infrared satellite imagery obtained at 8:10 p.m. AST on Monday indicates partly cloudy skies around the USVI and Puerto Rico.
MARINE WEATHER FORECAST
The National Weather Service noted that a small Northerly swell has impacted the USVI and Puerto Rico. Another northerly swell is forecast to approach the islands later this week.
On Tuesday, seas will be approximately 3 to 5 feet, occasional seas up to 6 feet, and with a swell period of 10 seconds. Winds will be out of the east at about 10 to 15 knots.
On Tuesday night, seas will be approximately 2 to 4 feet, occasional seas up to 5 feet, and with a swell period of 8 seconds. Winds will be out of the east-southeast at about 5 to 10 knots.
The water temperature is approximately 81-82°F, 27°C.

HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS
Small Northerly Swell: The National Weather Service noted that a small Northerly swell has impacted the USVI and Puerto Rico. Another northerly swell is forecast to approach the islands later this week.
Rip Currents: The rip current risk is expected to be moderate across most of the region on Tuesday.
Clear = Low Rip Current Risk
Yellow = Moderate Rip Current Risk
Red = High Rip Current Risk
Learn more about rip current safety in an interview between the NWS and the VI Source
https://stthomassource.com/content/2023/01/23/extreme-weather-in-the-caribbean-part-3-rip-currents/.
TROPIC WATCH
Tropical Activity: The
National Hurricane Center (NHC) does not expect any cyclonic development. November 30 was the last day of the 2023 Atlantic Hurricane Season! Please read a review of the season https://stthomassource.com/content/2023/11/29/colorado-state-university-reports-above-normal-2023-atlantic-hurricane-season-in-post-season-review/.
Days Until 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season: 152 Days
